questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents developmental delay. MRI shows demyelination in the central nervous system. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, and what enzyme deficiency causes this condition?
questions.explanation:
Disease

Enzyme deficiency

Features

Tay-Sachs disease

Hexosaminidase A,
  • Mental retardation
  • Blindness
  • Muscular weakness
  • Cherry red spots in macula

Fabry disease

α-Galactosidase
  • Skin rash(angiokeratoma)
  • Kidney failure (full symptoms only in males - X-linked recessive)

Krabbe disease (Option B)

β-Galactosidase
  • Mental retardation
  • Near absence of myelin
  • Predominant neurological manifestation and cranial nerves causing deafness and blindness.

Gaucher disease (Option D ruled out)

β-Glucosidase
  • Enlarged liver and spleen
  • Erosion of long bones
  • Mental retardation in infants
  • Anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia

Niemann-Pick disease (Option A ruled out)

Sphingomyelinase
  • Enlarged liver and spleen
  • Mental retardation
  • Fatal in early life
  • Cherry red spot in macula

Farber disease (Option C ruled out)

Ceramidase
  • Hoarseness
  • Dermatitis
  • Skeletal deformation
  • Mental retardation
  • Fatal in early life

questions.text: Which enzyme in snake venom hydrolyzes only sn-2 acyl bond of phospholipids?
Which of the following fatty acids is needed for humans from diet as humans cannot create double bonds beyond the 9th carbon from the carboxyl end of a fatty acid chain?
questions.explanation:
Essential fatty acids

Non-essential fatty acids
  • Cannot be synthesized by the human body and must be obtained through the diet.
  • Humans cannot create double bonds beyond the 9th carbon atom from the carboxyl end of a fatty acid chain.
  • Linoleic Acid (LA): An omega-6 fatty acid.
  • Alpha-linolenic acid (ALA): An omega-3 fatty acid. (Option A)
  • Can be synthesized by the human body from other dietary fats
  • Palmitic acid (Option B ruled out)
  • Oleic acid (Option C ruled out)
  • Stearic acid (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following lipids is characterized by its amphipathic nature, allowing it to form micelles in aqueous solutions?

Enzyme Deficiency

Tay-Sachs disease

Hexosaminidase A

Metachromatic leukodystrophy

Arylsulfatase A

Krabbe disease

β-Galactocerebrosidase

Gaucher disease

β-Glucosidase

Niemann-Pick disease types A, B

Sphingomyelinase

Farber disease

Ceramidase

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with episodic pain in his extremities, skin finding as shown in the image, and progressive renal dysfunction. A biopsy of the skin reveals the accumulation of ceramide trihexoside. An α-galactosidase deficiency is suspected. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Disease

Enzyme Deficiency

Lipid Accumulating

Clinical Symptoms

Tay-Sachs disease (Option A ruled out)

Hexosaminidase A, S

Cer—Glc—Gal(NeuAc) GalNAc GM2 Ganglioside

Mental retardation, blindness, muscular weakness

Cherry red spot

Fabry disease

(Option B)

α-Galactosidase

Cer—Glc—Gal—Gal Globotriaosylceramide

Skin rash (Angiokeratoma), kidney failure (symptoms manifest fully only in males; X-linked recessive)

Metachromatic leukodystrophy

Arylsulfatase A

Cer—Gal—OSO3 3-Sulfogalactosylceramide

Mental retardation and psychological disturbances in adults; demyelination

Krabbe disease

(Option C ruled out)

β-Galactosidase

Cer—Gal Galactosylceramide

Mental retardation; myelin almost absent

Gaucher disease

(Option D ruled out)

β-Glucosidase

Cer—Glc Glucosylceramide

Enlarged liver and spleen, erosion of long bones, mental retardation in infants

Niemann-Pick disease types A, B

Sphingomyelinase

Cer—P—choline Sphingomyelin

Enlarged liver and spleen, mental retardation; fatal in early life

Cherry red spot

Farber disease

Ceramidase

Acyl—Sphingosine Ceramide

Hoarseness, dermatitis, skeletal deformation, mental retardation; fatal in early life

Enzyme deficiency

Substance accumulation

Features

Tay-Sachs disease

Hexosaminidase A, S

Ganglioside (Option C)

  • Blindness
  • Muscular weakness
  • Cherry red spots in macula

Niemann-Pick disease

Sphingomyelinase

  • Enlarged liver and spleen

Farber disease

questions.text: Which of the following correctly matches the type of lipid with its description?

options.label: A
options.text: Fats - Liquid at room temperature, often containing polyunsaturated fatty acids.

options.label: B
options.text: Phospholipids - Contain glycerol and are the main lipid constituents of cell membranes.

options.label: C
options.text: Glycolipids - Esters of fatty acids that never contain sphingosine.

questions.correct_answer: B. Phospholipids - Contain glycerol and are the main lipid constituents of cell membranes.
questions.explanation:
Classification of lipids

1.Simple Lipids

  • Esters of fatty acids with various alcohols.
  • Further classified into fats, oils & waxes

Fats

Esters of fatty acids with glycerol; solid at room temperature. (Option A ruled out)

Triacylglycerol with saturated fatty acids.

Oils

Fats in liquid state at room temperature.

Triacylglycerols with polyunsaturated fatty acids.

Waxes

Esters of fatty acids with higher molecular weight monohydric alcohols.

  

2.Complex Lipids

  • Esters of fatty acids with alcohol and other groups.
  • Further classified based on additional groups present as Phospholipids, glycolipids and other complex lipids

Phospholipids:

  • Contain phosphoric acid;
  • Main lipid constituents of membranes.

(Option B)

Glycerophospholipids

Alcohol is glycerol.


Phosphatidylcholine, phosphatidylethanolamine.

Sphingophospholipids

Alcohol is sphingosine

  

Sphingomyelin, found in myelin sheaths.

Glycolipids:

(glycosphingolipids)

  • Contain fatty acid, sphingosine, and carbohydrate;
  • Involved in cell adhesion and recognition

(Option C ruled out)

Cerebrosides

(Option D ruled out)

Galactosylceramide, a key component of myelin.

Globosides

Cell adhesion and Pathogen identification

Gangliosides

Highly concentrated in nerve tissues and function in cell-cell recognition, communication, and as receptors for hormones and bacterial toxins.

Other Complex Lipids

Includes sulfolipids, amino lipids, and lipoproteins.

  

3.Precursor/Derived Lipids

Formed from hydrolysis of simple and complex lipids; Also act as precursors for lipid formation.

Fatty acids, cholesterol, fatty aldehydes, ketone bodies, hydrocarbons, lipid-soluble vitamins, hormones.

β-Galactosidase
  • Mental retardation

Gaucher disease (Option B ruled out)

β-Glucosidase
  • Enlarged liver and spleen
  • Erosion of long bones
  • Mental retardation in infants
  • Anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia

Niemann-Pick disease (Option A ruled out)

Sphingomyelinase
  • Enlarged liver and spleen
  • Mental retardation
  • Fatal in early life
  • Cherry red spot in macula

Farber disease

Ceramidase
  • Hoarseness
  • Dermatitis
  • Skeletal deformation
  • Mental retardation
  • Fatal in early life

 

Tay-Sachs disease

Sandhoff disease

Defective enzyme

Hexosaminidase A

GM2 Ganglioside

questions.text: Which component is present in gangliosides but not in cerebrosides or globosides?
questions.explanation:
Glycolipids

Composition

Cerebroside

Ceramide + monosaccharide (glucose or galactose) (Option A ruled out)

Globoside

Ceramide + oligosaccharide (glucose and galactose)

Ganglioside

Ceramide + oligosaccharide + NANA (N-acetyl Neuraminic Acid) (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following are the correct components of sphingomyelin?

A 30-year-old woman presents with a history of four consecutive miscarriages over the past three years. After a thorough evaluation, a diagnosis is made . Which of the following phospholipids is specifically antigenic in this disease?
questions.explanation:
Phospholipids

Location

  

Function

Synthesis

Significance

Phosphatidylserine

(Option A ruled out)

Inner leaflet of the plasma membrane
  • Involved in apoptosis.
  • It flips to the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane, serving as a signal for phagocytes to engulf the dying cell.

Synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)

Plays a role in blood clotting by facilitating the binding of clotting factors.

Supports neuronal function.

Cardiolipin

(Option C)

inner mitochondrial membrane
  • optimal function of numerous enzymes involved in mitochondrial energy metabolism.
  • Stabilizes the respiratory chain complexes and supercomplexes

Unique dimeric structure consisting of four fatty acid chains

Synthesized in the mitochondria from phosphatidylglycerol and cytidine diphosphate-diacylglycerol (CDP-DAG)

Antigenic

Phosphatidylinositol

(Option B ruled out)

plasma membrane and intracellular membranes
  • Involved in cell signaling pathways, particularly through the production of secondary messengers
  • Plays a role in membrane trafficking and cytoskeletal organization.

Produced in the ER and Golgi apparatus from CDP-DAG and inositol.

Crucial for the function of insulin signaling and other receptor-mediated signal transduction pathways.

Defects in phosphatidylinositol metabolism are linked to various diseases, including diabetes and cancer.

Phosphatidylethanolamine

(Option D ruled out)

All cellular membranes
  • Important for membrane fusion and the structural integrity of cellular membranes.
  • Serves as a precursor for the synthesis of phosphatidylserine.

Synthesized in the ER via the cytidine diphosphate-ethanolamine (CDP-ethanolamine) pathway or by decarboxylation of phosphatidylserine in the mitochondria.

Plays a role in lipid metabolism and membrane dynamics.

Deficiencies can impact cellular functions and are associated with various neurological disorders.

questions.text: What compound is formed when choline is added to the following structure?
questions.explanation:
Phospholipid

Composition

Lecithin (Option A)

Free phosphate + choline

Phosphatidylserine

Free phosphate + Serine

Phosphatidylinositol

Free phosphate + Inositol (Option D ruled out)

Cephalin

(Option B ruled out)

Free phosphate + Ethanolamine

Cardiolipin

(Option C ruled out)

Combination of Free phosphate group of 2 phosphatidate

questions.text: A premature baby presents with infant respiratory distress syndrome. The neonatologist says the neonate is yet to produce a type of phospholipid adequately. All of the following belong to the same class except?
questions.explanation:
Classification of Phospholipids(esters containing phosphate groups with fatty acid and alcohol.)

Glycerophospholipids
Alcohol: Glycerol

 


 

Phosphatidylcholine (Lecithin)

(Option C ruled out)

Most abundant in cell membranes, major source of choline.

Phosphatidylethanolamine (Cephalin)

(Option A ruled out)

Found in membranes; differs from phosphatidylcholine by choline substitution.

Phosphatidylserine

Similar to phosphatidylethanolamine; found in cell membranes.

Phosphatidylinositol

Contains myoinositol.

Cardiolipin

(Option B ruled out)

Found in mitochondria; synthesized from phosphatidylglycerol.

Lysophospholipids

Contains one acyl radical; e.g., lysophosphatidylcholine (lysolecithin).

Plasmalogens

10–30% of phospholipids in brain/heart; ether link instead of ester.

Sphingophospholipids

Alcohol: Sphingosine

Sphingomyelins

Found in myelin sheaths and cell membrane lipid rafts.
